results.title: About my dad
results.creator_credit: Huong Duy Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Like his father, Huong Duy Pham was also a soldier in the South Vietnam Army. But his family connections were to prove too dangerous and Huong eventually escaped by boat and made his way to Australia where he is now living with his wife and three sons. He dedicates this story to his father.

results.title: Signs of understanding
results.brief_description: Kris Chapman talks about the ACMI/Vicdeaf Project, its purpose and of the six deaf/hearing impaired people chosen to take part and contribute their stories and thoughts. With Auslan signing and subtitles.

results.title: Now I am an Australian
results.brief_description:
An migrated with her family to Australia and settled in Richmond. She is actively involved in the Vietnamese community and works toward keeping Vietnamese culture and traditions alive.
Made at ACMI as part of the ‘Recovering Hope’ Digital Storytelling project, in partnership with VicHealth and Belgium Street Neighbourhood House.

results.title: Life is beautiful
results.brief_description:
Nga’s children have been her motivating force to search for a better life. Nga reflects upon her family’s journey of migration from Vietnam to Australia. She is proud of her achievements and the achievements of her children.
Made at ACMI as part of the ‘Recovering Hope’ Digital Storytelling project, in partnership with VicHealth and Belgium Street Neighbourhood House.

results.title: Changing worlds: my journey
results.brief_description:
Mui Mui’s family fled China to Saigon and with the fall of Saigon they experience persecution and are again forced to flee. The journey from Vietnam to Australia is rough and dangerous with time spent in appalling conditions in a camp in Malaysia. Mui Mui reflects on how she and her family worked hard to adapt to a new country and create a new life.
Made at ACMI as part of the ‘Recovering Hope’ Digital Storytelling project, in partnership with VicHealth and Belgium Street Neighbourhood House.

results.title: Responding to change
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Penny Hendy describes her upbringing, her marriage as a “townie” to a “farmer” and her involvement with some 23 rural community organisations. As the women in her family before, Penny recognises the need to be resourceful, creative and flexible in response to change. Penny’s contribution to, and involvement with the Women in Grains has played a major role in her own life as well as the women she has mentored. Penny currently holds several high positions on various boards and continues to be a force within the rural community.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: Encouragement and growth
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Education was always a focus in Nickie Berrisford’s life. In this story Nickie tells of her upbringing, her marriage to a Horsham farmer, rural life and her four children. She openly speaks of her role as an educator, wife, and mother, and of her fourth child Laura who was born with Down Syndrome. Nickie has also been a mentor - encouraging, challenging and supporting the other women in the grain industry. This is her tribute to family, friends and bonds that have been formed, hopefully never to be broken.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: My Love
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
Almost 60 years old, Maureen Barry reminisces about her life, especially the last 35 years, of living on the land with the man she loves. From her youthful dreams as a young rural bride to the often harsh realiities of farm life in the sometimes unforgiving landscape of the Mallee. This story is dedicated to her husband, Brian.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: Mallee blossom
results.brief_description: This is Maureen Barry’s story of her life as a farmer, wife, mother and rural nurse in the dusty bowl of the Mallee in outback Victoria. She tells of the hardships and isolation, but also of the gradual blossoming of the land as both she and her husband keep pace with technology, embracing sustainable farming practices so as to leave the land in a better state for those who follow. This story is part of a project funded by VicHealth and partnership with the women’s rural network, Partners in Grain.

group.title: Against the grain: digital storytelling project

results.title: All change please
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop “Against the Grain” in association with Partners in Grain (PING).
“All change please. That’s what they say when the train is at the last station.” Diana Anderson began her journey around 23 years ago when she moved on to her husband’s family farm in north-west Victoria. Worked on for generations, Diana and Choco improved and changed the farming business, raising their two boys and enjoying the life for almost 23 years. That is until they were confronted with the distressing news the family partnership was to be sold. For Diana this was the end of one journey and the start of another - a new beginning.
